facts.text: In 2008, the Punjab State Water Supply Sewerage Board, Bhatinda issued notice inviting tender for extension and augmentation of water supply, sewerage scheme, pumping station and sewerage treatment plant for various towns on a turnkey basis.

anchor.surface_text: In 2008, the Punjab State Water Supply Sewerage Board, Bhatinda issued numberice inviting tender for extension and augmentation of water supply, sewerage scheme, pumping station and sewerage treatment plant for various towns mentioned therein on a turnkey basis.

facts.text: On 25.9.2008, the appellant company was awarded the tender after being found the best suited.

anchor.surface_text: On 25.9.2008, the appellant companypany, which is Signature Not Verified involved in civil electrical works in India, was awarded the said Digitally signed by NIDHI AHUJA Date 2019.03.11 173359 IST Reason tender after having been found to be the best suited for the task.

facts.text: On 16.1.2009, a formal contract was entered into between the appellant and respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: On 16.1.2009, a formal companytract was entered into between the appellant and respondent No. 2. It may be mentioned that the numberice inviting tender formed part and parcel of the formal agreement.

facts.text: The notice inviting tender formed part and parcel of the formal agreement.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the numberice inviting tender formed part and parcel of the formal agreement. Contained in the numberice inviting tender is a detailed arbitration clause.

facts.text: Clause 25 viii of the contract requires the party invoking arbitration to furnish a deposit-at-call for ten percent of the amount claimed.

anchor.surface_text: viii. It shall be an essential term of this companytract that in order to avoid frivolous claims the party invoking arbitration shall specify the dispute based on facts and calculations stating the amount claimed under each claim and shall furnish a deposit-at-call for ten percent of the amount claimed, on a schedule bank in the name of the Arbitrator by his official designation who shall keep the amount in deposit till the announcement of the award.

facts.text: The appellant had entered into similar contracts with respondent No. 2 containing the same arbitration clause.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had entered into similar companytracts with respondent No. 2 which companytained the same arbitration clause.

facts.text: Appellant addressed letters to respondent No. 2 regarding appointment of arbitrator in those matters and sought waiving the 10% deposit fee.

anchor.surface_text: It had therefore addressed letters to respondent No. 2 with regard to appointment of arbitrator in those matters and sought for waiving the 10 deposit fee.

facts.text: After no response, appellant filed Civil Writ Petition No. 18917 of 2016 before High Court of Punjab and Haryana.

anchor.surface_text: After having received numberresponse, the appellant had filed a writ petition, being Civil Writ Petition No. 18917 of 2016, before the High Court of Punjab and Haryana.

facts.text: Civil Writ Petition No. 18917 of 2016 was dismissed by High Court judgment dated 14.9.2016.

anchor.surface_text: This writ petition was dismissed by a judgment dated 14.9.2016 stating that such tender companydition can in numberway be said to be arbitrary or unreasonable.

facts.text: On 8.3.2017, appellant filed Civil Writ Petition No. 4882 of 2017 challenging validity of arbitration clause.

anchor.surface_text: On 8.3.2017, the appellant approached the High Court of Punjab and Haryana challenging the validity of this part of the arbitration clause by filing Civil Writ Petition No. 4882 of 2017.

facts.text: High Court dismissed Civil Writ Petition No. 4882 of 2017 by impugned judgment following earlier judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in the impugned judgment merely followed its earlier judgment and dismissed this writ petition as well.

facts.text: Leave granted by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: F. NARIMAN, J. Leave granted.

facts.text: Clause 25 viii provides that in event of award in favour of claimant, deposit refunded in proportion to amount awarded w.r.t amount claimed, balance forfeited.

anchor.surface_text: In the event of an award in favour of the claimant, the deposit shall be refunded to him in proportion to the amount awarded w.r.t the amount claimed and the balance, if any, shall be forfeited and paid to the other party.

facts.text: Clause 25 xv requires invoking and completing arbitration before civil court if issue covered by arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: xv. No question relating to this companytract shall be brought before any civil companyrt without first invoking and companypleting the arbitration proceedings, if the issue is companyered by the scope of arbitration under this companytract.

arguments.claim: Central Inland Water Transport Corpn. does not apply to commercial contracts between businessmen.

holdings.text: The argument of the appellant based on Central Inland Water Transport Corpn. must fail as it does not apply to commercial contracts between businessmen.

anchor.surface_text: As has correctly been argued by learned counsel appearing on behalf of the respondents, this Courts judgment in Central Inland Water Transport Corpn. supra , which lays down that contracts of adhesion... does not apply where both parties are businessmen and the contract is a commercial transaction see paragraph 89 of the said judgment . In this view of the matter, the argument of the appellant based on this judgment must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Brojo Nath concerns unconscionable contracts with unequal bargaining power between State and private persons, inapplicable to commercial transactions between businessmen.

holdings.text: S.K. Jain v. State of Haryana is wholly distinguishable and does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: This clause is materially different from clause 25 viii , which... makes it clear that in all cases the deposit is to be 10%... refund can only be in proportion... balance being forfeited... even though that other party may have lost the case. This being so, this judgment is wholly distinguishable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different security deposit structure scaled by claim amount with adjustment against costs and full refund of balance, unlike fixed 10% with proportional forfeiture regardless of outcome.

holdings.text: Even within the contractual sphere, state authorities or instrumentalities must act fairly, justly and reasonably as required by Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: In ABL International Ltd.... even within the contractual sphere, the requirement of Article 14 to act fairly, justly and reasonably by persons who are state authorities or instrumentalities continues.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies ABL International: State parties to contracts bound by Article 14 obligations to act fairly.

holdings.text: Clause 25 viii cannot be said to be discriminatory as it applies equally to both parties.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the learned counsel for the respondents that the aforesaid clause cannot be said to be discriminatory in that it applies equally to both respondent No. 2 and the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equal application to both parties precludes discrimination claim under Article 14.

holdings.text: Arbitrariness is a separate and distinct facet of Article 14 from discrimination.

anchor.surface_text: However, arbitrariness is a separate and distinct facet of Article 14. In A.L. Kalra... Art. 14 strikes at arbitrariness in executive administrative action because any action that is arbitrary must necessarily involve the negation of equality.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites Kalra, Nakara, Maneka Gandhi: arbitrary State action violates equality under Article 14 independently of discrimination.

holdings.text: Clause 25 viii is arbitrary and violative of Article 14 lacking nexus to preventing frivolous claims.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly, therefore, a deposit-at-call of 10% of the amount claimed... is obviously without any direct nexus to the filing of frivolous claims, as it applies to all claims - frivolous or otherwise - made at the very threshold.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deposit required upfront for all claims before any frivolousness determination; exemplary costs suffice for frivolous claims.

holdings.text: Proportional forfeiture under clause 25 viii renders it wholly arbitrary and disproportionate.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Successful claimant forfeits portion of deposit despite win; unjust enrichment of losing party without nexus to merits.

holdings.text: Deposit requirement is a clog on the arbitration process.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Contradicts policy of speedy, inexpensive ADR due to court congestion; deposit often exceeds court fees, deterring legitimate claims.

holdings.text: Frivolous claims can be adequately deterred by exemplary costs without deposit requirement.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that a frivolous claim can be dismissed with exemplary costs... It is therefore always open to the party who has succeeded before the arbitrator to invoke this principle.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents like Dnyandeo Sabaji Naik affirm exemplary costs as tool to penalize frivolous litigation.

anchor.surface_text: As has correctly been argued by learned counsel appearing on behalf of the respondents, this Courts judgment in Central Inland Water Transport Corpn. supra , which lays down that contracts of adhesion... does not apply where both parties are businessmen and the contract is a commercial transaction see paragraph 89 of the said judgment . In this view of the matter, the argument of the appellant based on this judgment must fail.
